Architect  with a passion for leveraging computational tools to address global challenges such as climate change, biodiversity loss, and urban sustainability. Currently, I am pursuing a PhD in the [Sustainable Design Group (**SDG**)](https://www.sustainabledesign.arct.cam.ac.uk/) at the University of Cambridge, where my research focuses on assessing the impacts of urban vegetation on sustainability in cities under.

I am a PhD student in architecture in the Sustainable Design Group at the University of Cambridge, supervised by Professor Ronita Bardhan. My research focuses on thermal resilience, specifically how the globalisation-driven paradigm shift in the design of building facades and envelope materials affects the thermal performance of buildings during extreme heat, particularly in projected climates a century from now. I hold a masterâ€™s degree in architecture and urban studies from the University of Cambridge and a bachelorâ€™s degree in architecture from the University of Nairobi. Beyond the scale of buildings, I am also interested in the impact of the urban environment on human health, particularly the growing challenge of urban heat stress. My work aims to map the complex interplay between Urbanisation, urban density, green infrastructure, and climate change, and their influence, especially in rapidly growing and unregulated cities like Nairobi, where unsustainable development increases vulnerability to extreme temperatures.

## Research

My curretn research integrates high-resolution LiDAR and aerial images of England to map trees in cities and, alongisde other geospatial datasets, assess the impact of urban vegetation in cities and its relationship to socio-economic indicators. I make heavy use of R, Python, Spark, Google Earth Engine, as well as specific tools for statistical modeling, machine learning, and data visualization.
